framework_comparison.details: RDF is the W3C recommended standard data model for directed edge-labelled graphs (Chunk 1:435-439)
Property graphs allow property-value pairs and labels on both nodes and edges; can be translated to/from directed edge-labelled graphs without loss (Chunk 1:548-567)
RDF Schema allows defining subclasses, subproperties, domains, and ranges for RDF graphs (Chunk 2:176-182)
Web Ontology Language supports richer semantics than RDFS for defining term meanings (Chunk 2:188-191, Chunk 3:350-356)
Shapes Constraint Language for validating graph data against shape constraints (Chunk 2:381-389)
Shape Expressions language for RDF graph validation (Chunk 2:381-385)
PROV Data Model specifies how provenance can be described in RDF graphs with entities, activities, and agents (Chunk 2:864-870)
DLs heavily influenced OWL; OWL 2 DL is a fragment restricted for decidable entailment (Chunk 4:127-189)
Rules correspond to positive Datalog in databases, Horn clauses in logic programming (Chunk 4:33-35)
Knowledge graphs use IRIs, metadata, and access protocols to satisfy FAIR principles (Chunk 7:617-718)
Knowledge graphs published following four Linked Data Principles for Web of Data (Chunk 7:728-774)
PROV Data Model used for capturing detailed provenance in KGs (Chunk 7:715-718)
DBpedia extracts graph-structured data from Wikipedia, multilingual with up to 97 languages (Chunk 8:458-502)
YAGO unifies Wikipedia with WordNet hierarchical structure (Chunk 8:504-541)
Wikidata is collaboratively edited KG supplying Wikipedia with data (Chunk 8:579-621)

ai_integration.description: Dense numerical representations of graph in low-dimensional vector space for machine learning tasks including link prediction, similarity, and recommendations (Chunk 4:767-822)
Custom neural network models adapted for graph-structured data, building network based on data graph topology for supervised learning (Chunk 5:393-446)
System for discovering meaningful rules from knowledge graphs with support and confidence measures, using PCA for incomplete data (Chunk 5:704-827)
End-to-end learning of rules using matrix multiplication for joins; NeuralLP uses attention for path-like rules (Chunk 5:868-909)
Learn embeddings where relations translate subject entities to object entities; used for link prediction (Chunk 4:907-961, Chunk 5:7-60)
Decompose graph tensor into latent factors for plausibility scoring (Chunk 5:63-237)
Use convolutional kernels over embeddings for neural plausibility scoring (Chunk 5:260-291)
Leverage word embedding techniques by generating graph sequences as sentences (Chunk 5:294-338)
Knowledge graphs enable 'things not strings' paradigm for web search (Chunk 8:726-745)
Bloomberg KG powers QA service and sentiment analysis (Chunk 8:810-817)
eBay uses KG for conversational agents in commerce (Chunk 8:758-763)
KGs used for product recommendations (Amazon, Airbnb, Uber Eats) (Chunk 8:750-777)
Entailment-aware embeddings incorporate rules/ontologies for plausibility (Chunk 9:9-13)
Message-passing computation model (Msg, Agg, End) for distributed graph processing
Rule mining and axiom mining for hypothesis induction from graphs

agentic_workflows.pattern: N/A - Paper predates agentic AI discussion
agentic_workflows.description: This 2020 paper focuses on knowledge graph foundations rather than AI agent orchestration patterns
Discovering links across knowledge graphs using similarity measures (Chunk 7:817-837)
Multi-stage fact validation using external sources (structured/unstructured) (Chunk 7:444-524)
Automated completion of missing edges via link prediction (Chunk 7:295-323)

generative_ai_patterns.pattern: N/A - Paper predates LLM integration discussion
generative_ai_patterns.description: Published before widespread LLM integration; focuses on traditional ML embeddings and neural networks for knowledge graphs

agent_ontology_integration.description: Extending queries to find solutions entailed by rules; OWL 2 QL profile designed for this (Chunk 4:92-109)
Applying rules recursively to graph, adding conclusions until fixpoint reached (Chunk 4:54-64)
Query rewriting approaches that support ontological entailments over virtualized data (Chunk 6:689-695)
Joint embeddings considering both data graph and rules (KALE, RUGE, FSL) using t-norm fuzzy logics (Chunk 5:341-390)
Graph pattern queries over RDF knowledge graphs (Chunk 8:108-135)
Edge pattern protocol for distributed querying (Chunk 8:65-106)
HTTP dereferencing for node-based access (Chunk 8:27-62)
Extract symbolic rules from knowledge graphs (Chunk 9:15-17)
Graph patterns, navigational queries, and path expressions for retrieval
Rules and Description Logics for inference over graphs
Embeddings and GNNs for learning latent representations

04-PROV-O_to_BFO_Semantic_Mapping.title: A semantic approach to mapping the Provenance Ontology to Basic Formal Ontology

framework_comparison.details: Total alignment of 153 classes and object properties. PROV Activity = BFO process; PROV Entity subclass of BFO continuant; PROV Agent subclass of BFO material entity
PROV Agent = CCO Agent intersection; PROV Person = CCO Person intersection; PROV Plan subclass of CCO Information Content Entity; PROV Start = CCO process beginning; PROV End = CCO process ending
25 terms explicitly mapped using 26 subsumption relations. wasDerivedFrom mapped to RO causally influenced by
Alignments tested for consistency with PROV-SOSA alignment; no inconsistencies found

agent_ontology_integration.description: Alignment enables SPARQL queries over PROV-O data using BFO classes; semantic reasoners can discover implicit information
HermiT reasoner used to test consistency and materialize inferences from combined ontologies
Alignments used to automatically detect mistakes in canonical PROV-O examples

15-SciAgents_Multi-Agent_Graph_Reasoning.title: SciAgents: Automating Scientific Discovery through Multi-Agent Intelligent Graph Reasoning

framework_comparison.details: Multi-agent systems overcome limitations of single agents for complex scientific discovery
Uses AutoGen framework for automated multi-agent collaboration
Provides scale, precision, and exploratory power surpassing traditional methods
Uses tool calling and function invocation patterns; extends with domain-specific agents

ai_integration.description: LLMs use sub-graphs from ontological knowledge graphs as context for reasoning
Knowledge graph paths provide structured context for generating research hypotheses
Retrieval of relevant sub-graphs from comprehensive knowledge graphs to augment LLM capabilities
Agents equipped with external tools like Semantic Scholar API for novelty assessment
Uses generate_path function to create knowledge paths between concepts for research ideation
Specialized agents (planner, ontologist, scientist, etc.) collaborate in structured workflow
Assistant agent calls functions like generate_path and rate_novelty_feasibility
Research proposals with seven standardized aspects (hypothesis, outcome, mechanism, design principles, unexpected properties, comparison, novelty)

agentic_workflows.description: Discovery workflow systematically broken into manageable subtasks assigned to specialized agents
First approach with predefined sequence ensuring consistency and reliability
Second approach with no predetermined order, flexible and adaptive framework
Agents negotiate via adversarial interactions to produce sound predictions
Modular, hierarchically organized swarm similar to biological systems
Multiple iterations modeling process of negotiation during thinking and reflecting
6-step workflow: generate path -> define terms -> craft proposal -> expand aspects -> critique -> rate novelty/feasibility
Seven specialized agents expand different aspects: hypothesis, outcome, mechanism, design_principles, unexpected_properties, comparison, novelty
Random keywords generate knowledge paths between concepts for novel research ideation
Caller agent explicitly selects next agent to speak after each output

generative_ai_patterns.description: Agents optimized through carefully crafted prompts for targeted expertise
Models generate structured output with hypothesis, outcome, mechanisms, design principles, unexpected properties, comparison, novelty
Agents provide clear rationale and step-by-step reasoning for proposals
Answers successively refined and improved through iterative prompting
Nuanced reasoning through multiple iterations vs zero-shot answers
LLM generates research proposals with standardized sections: hypothesis, outcomes, mechanisms, design principles, unexpected properties, comparisons, novelty
Assistant calls generate_path and rate_novelty_feasibility functions
Ontologist synthesizes definitions and relationships from knowledge graph paths
Critic agent generates structured strengths/weaknesses/improvements analysis
Novelty and feasibility rated on numeric scales (e.g., Novelty: 8/10, Feasibility: 7/10)

agent_ontology_integration.description: Random path approach extracts diverse concepts from global knowledge graph
Dedicated agent applies advanced reasoning to synthesize and interpret knowledge graph data
Sub-graph forms basis for generating structured research hypotheses
In automated approach, agents share memory with full visibility of collaboration history
Tool assesses novelty of hypotheses against existing literature
Agents traverse knowledge graph to find relationships between concepts (e.g., 'collagen -- enhanced through -- mechanical properties')
Ontologist agent extracts and defines terms from knowledge paths, establishing relationships
Research proposals built on explicit relationships like 'allows for', 'achieved through', 'is a metric for'
Knowledge graphs encode domain expertise (materials science, biology) that guides agent reasoning

16-KG-Agent_Knowledge_Graph_Reasoning.title: KG-Agent: An Efficient Autonomous Agent Framework for Complex Reasoning over Knowledge Graph

framework_comparison.details: KG-Agent applies ReAct-style reasoning-action loop specifically for KG traversal with specialized toolbox
Both use memory management and external tools, but KG-Agent specializes for KG with smaller LLM
KG-Agent uses autonomous reasoning vs StructGPT's pre-defined interaction patterns
KG-Agent adds tool support and works with smaller open-source LLM

ai_integration.description: LLM generates function calls to toolbox for KG operations
Four-part memory (question, toolbox, KG info, history) guides LLM decisions
Synthesize reasoning programs from KGQA datasets to fine-tune small LLM
7B LLM achieves autonomous reasoning via specialized instruction tuning

agentic_workflows.description: Planner selects tool from toolbox based on knowledge memory, executor runs it, memory updates
LLM planner + toolbox + KG executor + knowledge memory integrated framework
Complex query decomposed into sequential function calls traversing KG
Agent uses 'end' tool to return final answers when reasoning complete

generative_ai_patterns.description: Reasoning steps formulated as executable function calls in code format
SQL queries converted to reasoning programs then to instruction tuning data
Interleaved reasoning (tool selection) and acting (tool execution) pattern
10K training samples enable zero-shot transfer to new KGs and domains

agent_ontology_integration.description: Structured memory provides ontological context for LLM reasoning
Tools abstract KG structure, providing typed operations on entities/relations
Questions grounded to KG subgraph structure before reasoning
Agent uses get_relation to discover traversal options from current entities

framework_comparison.details: OWL 2 based on SROIQ DL provides schema language for KGs with rich expressive power
Translation-based embedding using ||h+r-t|| as score function
Complex vector space for asymmetric relations
Rotation in complex space for compositional relations
Structured query language for KG retrieval and manipulation

ai_integration.description: Combining logic-based and embedding-based reasoning for robust KG inference
Embeddings deal with data noise and predict plausible but non-determined knowledge
NTP enables Prolog to learn embeddings and compare symbols via vector similarity
Use embeddings to guide/prune search during rule learning

ReasonKGE uses schema-incorrect triples for negative sampling

18-Multi-Agent_Architecture_Taxonomy_LLM.title: Balancing Autonomy and Alignment: A Multi-Dimensional Taxonomy for Autonomous LLM-Powered Multi-Agent Architectures

framework_comparison.details: Adapts the 4+1 view model to LLM-powered multi-agent systems with four viewpoints: Goal-driven Task Management, Agent Composition, Multi-Agent Collaboration, Context Interaction
Extends beyond Wooldridge/Jennings, Brustoloni, Maes, Franklin/Graesser taxonomies by incorporating LLM-specific aspects and autonomy-alignment interplay
Extends beyond Bird, Dudek, Van Dyke Parunak, Moya taxonomies developed pre-LLM era

ai_integration.description: Agents derive reasoning capabilities from LLMs for reflecting, planning, and processing tasks
Agent prompts undergo augmentation integrating role, memory, context information, and prompt templates before LLM processing
Agents leverage contextual resources (tools, data, foundation models) via API integration

agentic_workflows.description: Systems tackle user-prompted goals by breaking them into smaller manageable tasks assigned to specialized agents
Three core phases: Decomposition (breaking down goals), Orchestration (distributing tasks), Synthesis (combining results)
Execution chains with predefined action sequences and well-defined endpoints
Alternating DelegateTask and ExecuteTask actions between two agents creating instruction-execution feedback loops
Interactions between generic agent types allowing greater dynamism
L0 Static (rule-based), L1 Adaptive (framework-guided), L2 Self-Organizing (LLM-driven decisions)

generative_ai_patterns.description: Direct agent collaborations rely on prompt-driven message exchange sequences or cycles
LLM capabilities employed for reflecting memories, observing results, planning steps, weighing options
Agent-driven prompt engineering pivotal for multi-agent systems
Systems employ single-turn prompting to convey intricate goals with instructions, exemplifications, role specifications

agent_ontology_integration.description: UML class diagram structuring architectural concepts and relations for LLM-powered multi-agent systems
Domain ontologies devised as conceptual models to support human understanding of the addressed domain
Taxonomic structure organized through feature diagrams expressing hierarchical structure and dependencies

19-Graph_of_Thoughts_LLM_Reasoning.title: Graph of Thoughts: Solving Elaborate Problems with Large Language Models

framework_comparison.details: GoT generalizes CoT from linear chain to arbitrary graph, enabling aggregation and more complex reasoning patterns
GoT generalizes ToT from tree to arbitrary graph, enabling thought aggregation and feedback loops
GoT encompasses CoT-SC's multiple chains but adds ability to aggregate and combine thoughts

ai_integration.description: Models LLM reasoning as arbitrary graph where thoughts are vertices and dependencies are edges, enabling novel transformations
Controller, Prompter, Parser, Scorer modules enable extensible prompt engineering with different LLMs (GPT-3.5, GPT-4, Llama-2)
Complex tasks decomposed into subtasks solved independently, then merged via graph aggregation
LLM generates multiple candidate solutions (k=5 or k=10), scores them locally, keeps best N
Complex problems split into subproblems (e.g., 128 elements into 8 parts of 16)
Generate operations try to improve solutions after aggregation

agentic_workflows.description: Static structure prescribing execution plan of thought operations with predecessor/successor relationships
Dynamic structure maintaining state of ongoing LLM reasoning process including executed operations and thought states
Workflow pattern: generate multiple thoughts, score each, keep best, then aggregate for final solution
Multi-level aggregation: split into 8 parts, merge pairwise in 3 levels
After each operation, score results locally and keep best N

generative_ai_patterns.description: Framework modeling LLM reasoning as arbitrary graph, enabling aggregation, refinement loops, and complex thought transformations
Combining arbitrary thoughts into new ones by creating vertices with multiple incoming edges, reinforcing advantages while eliminating disadvantages
Iterative improvement of a thought via self-loop in graph: V+ = {} and E+ = {(v, v)}
Generating one or more new thoughts from existing thought, embracing ToT/CoT-SC generation patterns
GoT achieves both low latency (log_k N) and high volume (N) through aggregation, unlike ToT which has low volume
Tasks decomposed into subtasks, solved individually, then incrementally merged for final result
Prompts structured as operations in a directed graph (Generate, Score, Aggregate)
Generate(k=N) produces N candidate solutions for subsequent scoring
Final score computed as harmonic mean of redundancy and retained information
Outputs wrapped in XML-like tags for extraction (e.g., <Merged>, <Redundancy>, <Retained>)
LLM scores merged documents on redundancy and retained information criteria
Prompt asks to improve merged result by adding information and removing redundancy

agent_ontology_integration.description: Graph structure provides ontological framework for organizing and relating LLM thoughts and their dependencies
Supports heterogeneous graphs G = (V, E, c) where c maps vertices to different classes (e.g., plans vs paragraphs)
Evaluation function E(v, G, p_theta) and ranking function R(G, p_theta, h) for thought quality assessment

23-UFO_Story_Ontological_Foundations.title: Towards ontological foundations for conceptual modeling: The unified foundational ontology (UFO) story

entity_types.name: Endurant
entity_types.description: Entities wholly present at any time they exist (objects, substances)
entity_types.quote: UFO-A: An Ontology of Endurants dealing with structural conceptual modeling...

entity_types.name: Perdurant
entity_types.description: Entities that unfold in time, having temporal parts (events, processes)
entity_types.quote: UFO-B: An Ontology of Perdurants dealing with Mereology, Temporal Ordering...

entity_types.name: Intentional Entity
entity_types.description: Mental states and intentional phenomena (beliefs, desires, intentions, goals)
entity_types.quote: notions such as Beliefs, Desires, Intentions, Goals, Actions...

entity_types.name: Social Entity
entity_types.description: Social constructs and relational complexes (commitments, claims, social roles)
entity_types.quote: Commitments and Claims, Social Roles and Social Particularized Relational Complexes...

entity_types.name: Moment (Trope/Mode/Quality)
entity_types.description: Particularized properties - existentially dependent on bearers
entity_types.quote: accidents (particularized properties, moments, qualities, modes, tropes)...

entity_types.name: Substance Sortal (Kind)
entity_types.description: Types that supply identity criteria to their instances

entity_types.name: Relator
entity_types.description: Particularized relational properties that ground material relations

framework_comparison.details: BWW based on Bunge's philosophy of science inadequate for conceptual modeling which requires descriptive metaphysics accounting for cognition and linguistic competence

framework_comparison.relationship: unifies with GFO to create UFO
framework_comparison.details: Both DOLCE and GFO based on Aristotelian Square (Four-Category Ontologies), but DOLCE lacks universals as category and rich theory of relations

framework_comparison.relationship: unifies with DOLCE to create UFO
framework_comparison.details: GFO theory of relations subject to Bradley Regress making it unsuitable for conceptual modeling applications
UFO systematizes notions pervasive in conceptual modeling (types, roles, phases, mixins) that OntoClean addresses partially
OntoUML is ontologically well-founded version of UML 2.0 class diagrams

framework_comparison.compared_to: TOGAF, ArchiMate, RM-ODP, TROPOS, AORML, ARIS, BPMN
framework_comparison.details: UFO employed as basis for analyzing, reengineering and integrating many modeling languages and standards
